And to put it all together, we will use, we'll go through a demo for you. So Google really has been working with data NAI since its early days, all the way back in 1998. And there's several reasons why they've done this. So they then moved on into the Google cloud platform to provide secure and flexible computing services. And they already had all this infrastructure to massive data centers to support its own products like search and Gmail. So GCP has helped them leverage this existing infrastructure and then offer it as a service to other business. And also to offer expertise in areas like AI and ML to businesses through the cloud. The other great thing about GCP is it allows businesses to scale their resources up and down as needed, which is of course more cost-effective than traditional on-prem architecture. So we've talked a lot about this infrastructure and you can think of it like this kind of sandwich structure. So at the base layer here is networking and security, which lays the foundation to support all of the Google cloud infrastructure. So Google offers a few security options. Like you may have heard cloud armor, which safeguards against denial of service attacks. And threat network detection systems. But networking security isn't really covered in this module. You can find it in other modules, but today we're interested in this top section here. Big data ML products and compute and storage. So on our infrastructure sandwich, next layer are compute and storage. And this layer is kind of split in two because Google cloud actually separates or decouples this on purpose. So they can independently scale based on need. So you don't have to scale them both when you only need one more than the other. So for compute, we've got compute engines and cloud functions, which were covered in the infrastructure talk. And for storage, we have database products, which we will look at called cloud spanner, big table and cloud SQL. And here on the top layer, we have the big data and ML products, which use the compute and storage layer to perform ingestion, processing, and essentially deliver your business insights on your data pipelines. And thanks to Google cloud, you can do all of these tasks without needing to deep dive into managing it yourself. So just as a recap, this course focuses on the middle layer here, compute and storage, and the top layer in blue, big data and ML products. So let's start with compute. So Google cloud's infrastructure is based in five major geographic locations, North America, South America, Europe, Asia, and Australia. And the reason there are multiple service locations, it's because choosing where to locate apps affects qualities like availability, durability, and latency, which measures how long it takes information to travel for its source to destination. And we'll look at availability and durability soon. And you can check out a map on cloud.google.com forward slash about locations. And I like this because it's kind of like a dashboard, which gives you some highlights at the top. And you can see exactly how many regions, zones and territories there are. And I'm sure you are really interested to know what they mean. And we'll look at those in a second. And below, you can dive into a network map. And you can also check out where the regions are. So each of these geographical locations here are divided into several regions. And then the regions are separated into zones. So the hierarchy goes location, regions, zones. And regions represent independent geographic areas. They are comprised of zones. For example, I'm currently in London, and in London, there is a zone called Europe West 2A, Europe West 2B, and Europe West 2C. And these regions, Google, GCP divides its data centers into different zones. GCP divides its data centers into geographic regions, and they're physically separated from each other, which offers a level of fault tolerance. So this means an outage in one region, Europe West 2, doesn't affect an outage in another region, for example, Europe West 3. And a zone is where your resources are deployed. So let's say, for example, you launch a VM, virtual machine, using Compute Engine, more about Compute Engine later, it will run in the zone you specify. So if I launched a virtual machine in Europe West 2B, it would launch in that zone. And zonal resources operate within that single zone, which means that if a zone becomes available, the resources in that zone won't become available either. So you can launch your Compute Engine instance across multiple zones within a region, and this way, if an outage hits one zone, your app can still function using instances in other zones. And Google Cloud lets users specify geographical locations to run services and resources, and you can specify resources on a zonal, region, or multi-regional level. And this is useful for bringing applications closer to users around the world, and then the second reason you might do that is to deploy resources in a region that is not in the zone. So let's say, for example, you launch a virtual machine in Europe West 2, and you do that, it deploy resources in a multi-regional zone is for protection against issues with an entire region, for example, due to a natural disaster. And some of Google Cloud services support placing resources in what we call a multi-region, for example, Cloud Spanner, which is a SQL database optimized, I think it's about 100 writes per second. So if you are, if you're trying to store data from some kind of really popular web app on Black Friday, then the multi-region configuration that you can do through Cloud Spanner allows you to replicate the database, not just in multiple zones, but in multiple zones across regions. And these additional replicas enable you to read data with a low latency, because you can read it from multiple locations that are close to or within your region. And currently Google Cloud supports 112 zones in 37 regions, and you can find the most up-to-date information on the app tab I just showed you. And now we can focus our attention on compute and storage. Organizations with growing data often require lots of compute power to run big data jobs. So running LLMs for GenAI purposes as large language models for generative AI purposes, just as an example. The need for large language models is a lot more important than just the need for compute power only grows with that. And Google Cloud offers a range of these services, which includes Compute Engine, Google Kubernetes Engine, App Engine, Cloud Functions and Cloud Run. And we are now going to go into these one by one. So let's start with Compute Engine. Compute Engine is an infrastructure as a service offering, which provides compute, storage and network resources that are similar to physical data centers. So if you had an on-premise data center, you own all the hardware and you decide what to do with it. This is kind of like making a pizza from scratch in your own home. However, when we use an infrastructure as a service offering, this is like renting the restaurant and the kitchen, paying for gas, but you manage the recipe and the cooking. So in this example, the cloud service provider manages the hardware. And infrastructure as a service offerings provide raw compute, storage and network capabilities. And they're organized virtually into resources similar to physical data centers, but they're all virtual. The second is Google Kubernetes Engine or GKE. GKE runs on containerized apps in a cloud environment, as opposed to on an individual virtual machine like Compute Engine. So a container... That was quite a few slides ahead. So a containerized app contains your compute. And it's packaged up with all the dependencies that you need. ML models can be packaged as containerized apps, and GKE can be used to deploy and manage these models, allowing you to kind of scale them up and down based on prediction requests. And the reason you might do this is because it makes app development really efficient, rapid, and really quite secure if you can ensure all those dependencies are in there. Compute Engine essentially offers more control, but requires more management effort. And containerized apps on Kubernetes provide a more automated and scalable approach. So that's kind of a practical difference between those two. So the third computing service is App Engine. And this is a service for hosting web apps at scale. So let's say you're developing a new blog platform that allows users to create accounts, write and publish blog posts, and even leave some comments. So you'd use App Engine to provide support for everything you need for your web app. And it has support for popular languages and frameworks like Python, Java, Go, PHP. And this allows developers to leverage their existing skills and then quickly deploy their code. And it's a fully managed platform as a service offering. And this is like in a restaurant analogy, this is like renting just a chef as a service. So in this example, the vendor manages all the other infrastructure and you only manage the recipe. So for platform as a service offerings, you rent all the physical hardware, but you only manage the customizable elements specific to your solution. And PAs, past offerings bind code to libraries that provide access to the infrastructure the application needs. So practically, what does this mean? It means that you can allow resources to be only focused on the logic of your app. So let's talk about the difference between App Engine, GKE and Compute Engine then. So you would use Compute Engine if you need maximum control over your environment, or you have specific OS needs. Then you'd use App Engine, platform as a service, if you want to prioritize developer experience, and you have a web app in a supported framework and you need automatic support. And you have a web app in a supported framework and you need automatic scaling. And you'd use Kubernetes, Google Kubernetes Engine if you need a bit more fine grained control over your environment and you have complex requirements. And the fourth compute we have mentioned in our list is Cloud Functions. And Cloud Functions execute code in response to some kind of event. And a good example of using a Cloud Function in GCP is for real-time image processing. So let's imagine you have a mobile app that allows users to upload photos. So here's how a Cloud Function can be used in this scenario. So the trigger, the first step, let's say a user uploads an image. So the first step, the user uploads an image to a Cloud Storage bucket. This event triggers the Cloud Function, which is designed to process the uploaded image. And then within the Cloud Function, your code can download the uploaded image, resize it to create a thumbnail, and then upload the thumbnail to a separate Cloud Storage folder. That way, when you take a photo, you can in real-time view a thumbnail of that photo and you don't have to guess which photo you are trying to view. And Cloud Functions are function as a service. And they're often referred to in this way as it's a completely serverless execution environment. And this means you don't need to install any software locally to run the code, and you don't have to provision or manage any servers. All you're interested in is the event and the action. So let's say you have a Cloud Function that you want to run, and you want to run the action. And finally, there is Cloud Run, which is a fully managed platform that enables you to run requests or event-driven workloads without having to worry about services. It takes away all of the infrastructure management, so you can focus on writing code. And you can think of Cloud Functions and Cloud Run in two ways, and this is how I like to think of them. So Cloud Functions you can think of as like a vending machine. You push a trigger and the vending machine dispenses a product. It executes your code and it's really good for small tasks, simple tasks. But Cloud Run you think of as the full kitchen. You have all of the containers and you want to prepare a variety of complex code. So you want to use Cloud Run for more complicated events and it offers more control, but it does require more set up effort. So in short, if you have a simple event-driven task, Cloud Functions is a really good option. But if you need more flexibility or control, then use Cloud Run as it's a better choice. And I talked about automatically creating thumbnails for photos earlier with Google Photos. But let's talk about another way that Google Photos relies on compute capability. And it does this to implement video stabilisation. And this takes an unstable video and stabilises it to minimise movement. And for this stabilisation to work as intended, you need the proper data, which is the video itself. And a video is really a large collection of individual images. And you need, so you need the. So you need the images. So you need the images. That's a sun, excuse my drawing. And you also need the time series information. On the camera's position and orientation from the onboard gyroscope, so you know how to orient the image. And even just a short video requires like over a billion data points. To feed the ML model in order to create a stabilised version. And as of 2020, which was four years ago now, roughly 28 billion photos and videos were uploaded to Google Photos every week. And I think that was more than four trillion photos. And that number is only exponentially increased since then. So for the video stabilisation service to work, you need a lot of data. And to ensure it works as intended. And accurately, the Google Photos team needed to develop, train and serve a really high performing machine learning model on millions and millions of videos. And that is a very large data set. And just as the hardware on a standard PC will definitely not have to process a big data job for an organisation, even now, the hardware on your smartphone is still not powerful enough to train sophisticated ML models. And that's why Google trains production ML models on a really vast network of data centres and then deploys smaller trained version of the models onto your phone. So you can access the capabilities of that video stabilisation software directly in your palm. But where does all this processing power come from? And since 2020, the required computing power has actually been doubling approximately every three and a half months. So that's a very exponential increase. This means that hardware manufacturers have run up against limitations and CPUs, central processing units and GPUs, graphics processing units, they can't adequately scale to reach the huge demand we have for ML. And to help overcome this challenge in 2016, Google introduced the TPU, the tensor processing unit. And this is an application.
